title: Correcting Body Angle and Posture in Headshot Photography
summary: Photographer Peter Hurley explains how to correct a common posing mistake where subjects angle their bodies away from the camera, creating an unflattering 'lean back' look. He demonstrates two techniques—the 'Hook' and the 'Golfing' move—to straighten the subject's body line relative to the frame, and discusses camera tilting techniques to further refine the composition.

steps.action: Identify the common mistake where the subject's body angles out of the frame while the head tilts back in.
Apply the 'Hook' technique: Instruct the subject to imagine a hook pulling the top of their head up, then push their forehead out and down.
Introduce the 'Golfing' analogy if the hook technique doesn't fully correct the posture.
Instruct the subject to stand sideways, imagine holding a putter, and raise their hands/the ball up to straighten their spine and body line.
Have the subject lean forward slightly while maintaining the straight 'golfing' posture to engage with the camera.
Review the images to compare the 'leaning back' pose versus the corrected straight posture.
Use the 'Untilt' technique: Tilt the camera to match the angle of the subject's forward lean, ensuring their body line remains parallel to the side of the frame.

key_takeaways: Avoid allowing the subject's body to angle out of the frame, as it makes them appear wider and the pose look awkward.
The subject's body line should be vertical or parallel to the side of the frame for a slimming effect.
The 'Golfing' visualization helps subjects straighten their spine and correct backward leaning.
Tilting the camera to match a subject's forward lean ('untilting') can help maintain a straight body line in the final composition.
